newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds rangebound in muted trading.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds rangebound in muted trading.

text.p: Argentine bonds were little changed in quiet trading Monday, with players awaiting the release of a slew of U.S. economic indicators starting Tuesday, dealers said.

"So far things have been very quiet because everyone's waiting for the U.S. data," a dealer at a leading foreign bank said. "Prices are underpinned by the prevailing optimistic trading environment in New York and strength in the local futures market."
Argentina's FRB Brady bond due 2005 was flat at 95-1/4 while the dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 4 due 2002 dipped $0.10 to 118.65.

"We think the U.S. indicators, starting with the release of the Employment Cost Index tomorrow, will be good," another dealer said. "U.S. long bond yields are likely to stay below 6.5 percent this week, guaranteeing strong liquidity in the local markets."
U.S. new home sales numbers were also due out Tuesday while gross domestic product estimates will be released Wednesday and July nonfarm payrolls Friday.
Traders said no new local news was affecting the market although the strong performance of the Argentine economy in the second quarter remained a key positive factor.
